description.narrative:
Aga Khan Foundation Afghanistan (AKF-A) har inkommit med en ansökan till Sida om projektstöd för åren 2015-2019 om totalt 100 000 000 SEK för att stärka den privata sektorn i Afghanistan. Projektet är uppdelat i två faser (24 månader respektive 36 månader) om 20 000 000 SEK per år. Sida ämnar ingå avtal om 24 initiala månader totalt uppgående till 40 000 000 SEK. En ny prövning sker därefter för en eventuell förlängning, med grund i en, av Sida initierad, extern utvärdering. Sidas intention är dock att fortsatt stödja projektet under fas 2. Projektet finansieras till fullo av svenska medel.
Insatsen ämnar uppnå: i) en ökad produktivitet inom jordbrukssektorn ii) stärkta möjligheter till hållbart företagande inom valda värdekedjor iii) ökat ekonomiskt deltagande av kvinnor
Projektet implementeras i sju provinser i nordöstra Afghanistan (Badakhshan, Takhar, Kunduz, Samangan, Baghlan, Parwan och Bamyan).
Sidas stöd till AKF-A regleras genom insatsavtal om projektstöd till civilsamhällesorganisation där vidareförmedling av pengar till tredjepart sker. Avtalsmallen har beslutsnummer 2015-000433. Avsteg från avtalsmallen har gjorts gällande frekvens av utbetalningar vilket stipuleras i Annex II till avtalet under Artikel 14.1. Artikeln hänförs från insatshanteringsregelns Artikel 2.8. Utbetalningar skall ske vid flertalet tillfällen under ett verksamhetsår samt i nära anslutning till användande och i takt med medelbehov. Avsteg från ordinarie sekvensering har gjorts i Artikel 3 i avtalet då den första utbetalningen sker sent på året och 2015 års anslagsallokering redan fastslagits. Resterande medel utbetalas i en andra utbetalning, 3e kvartalet 2016, då den är villkorad på en granskning av organisationens interna styrning och kontroll (ISK), samt årlig rapportering.
The project aims to contribute to economic development in the chosen provinces and districts.

To stimulate economic development by supporting economic drivers in selected agricultural value chains through 1) creating opportunities for enterprises to develop within and across selected value chains and 2) by building a gender inclusive enabling environment for private sector growth.

description.narrative: The first two-year phase of SPEDA was implemented by Aga Khan Foundation Afghanistan (AKF-A) in an way as a proof of concept project. Originally, AKF-A had presented the SPEDA concept to Sida as a five year project. As AKF-A was then a new partner for Sida, it was decided to phase the intervention into two parts where Sida could take stock of the project towards the end of the first phase. SPEDA I was extended by three months partly to capture results projected to be achieved just beyond the end of the first project period and also to facilitate a smooth transition to the second phase of SPEDA which Sida in October 2017 agreed to finance over three years. The closure of this contribution has been severely delayed do to complications in AKF-As audit process of third parties. (Please see statement on audited financial report for full explanation). Overall the SPEDA I project has overshot the targets set by the project, this goes for both Objective 1) To create opportunities for MSMEs to develop within and across selected value chains and for Objective 2) To build a gender inclusive enabling environment for private sector growth. Under the SPEDA I project farmers have improved their productivity and incomes. Farmers have, according to the reporting from the project accessed new commercial channels through which to sell their products. They have also been able to negotiate better prices for their produce with buyers. Better access to services such as transport were also mentioned by farmers targeted by the project as a factor contributing to their improved incomes. The results are however of an output based character and it is not yet proved that the changes in production practices, services delivery mechanisms or female entrepreneurship will last beyond the project (that is beyond the SPEDA II horizon). It is Sida's assessment that the achievement of results are still dependent on the continued support form the project such as training of farmers and cost-sharing arrangements with private companies.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
